docs.text:
1. isTauri detection utility - Single check for runtime environment 

    export const isTauri = () => '__TAURI__' in window || '__TAURI_INTERNALS__' in window

  2. Guard existing listen() call - Prevent crash on App.tsx:617 

    if (isTauri()) {
  const unlisten = listen<string>('menu-event', handler)
}

  3. localStorage fallback for preferences - Already using Zustand with persist

docs.title: Option A: In-Memory Mock Database (Recommended)
docs.text:
Pros: Fast, no external deps, mirrors test setup pattern Cons: Data lost on refresh, no persistence

// src/renderer/src/lib/browser-api.ts
import { Note, Project, Tag } from '../types'

class BrowserMockDB {
  private notes: Map<string, Note> = new Map()
  private projects: Map<string, Project> = new Map()
  private tags: Map<string, Tag> = new Map()

  // Seed with demo data on init
  constructor() {
    this.seedDemoData()
  }

  createNote(note: Partial<Note>): Note {
    const id = crypto.randomUUID()
    const newNote = { id, ...note, created_at: new Date().toISOString() }
    this.notes.set(id, newNote)
    return newNote
  }

  // ... all 46 API methods
}

export const browserDB = new BrowserMockDB()

Implementation: 1. Create browser-api.ts with in-memory store 2. Create api-factory.ts that returns real or mock API 3. Seed with demo projects/notes for testing

docs.title: Option B: IndexedDB Persistence
docs.text:
Pros: Data persists across refresh, closer to real DB Cons: More complex, async everywhere, migration headaches

// Using Dexie.js for cleaner IndexedDB API
import Dexie from 'dexie'

class ScribeDB extends Dexie {
  notes!: Table<Note>
  projects!: Table<Project>
  tags!: Table<Tag>

  constructor() {
    super('scribe-browser')
    this.version(1).stores({
      notes: 'id, title, folder, project_id, created_at',
      projects: 'id, name, type',
      tags: 'id, name'
    })
  }
}

docs.title: Option C: API Factory Pattern (Cleanest Architecture)
docs.text:
Pros: Clean separation, easy to swap implementations Cons: Requires refactoring api.ts imports throughout codebase

// src/renderer/src/lib/api-factory.ts
import { api as tauriApi } from './tauri-api'
import { api as browserApi } from './browser-api'

export const isTauri = () => '__TAURI__' in window

export const api = isTauri() ? tauriApi : browserApi

File Structure: 

src/renderer/src/lib/
├── api.ts              # Current file → rename to tauri-api.ts
├── tauri-api.ts        # Real Tauri invoke calls
├── browser-api.ts      # In-memory/IndexedDB mock
├── api-factory.ts      # Runtime detection + export
└── demo-data.ts        # Seed data for browser mode

docs.title: Scribe Dual Runtime Architecture
docs.text: Generated: 2025-12-28 Context: Understanding Tauri vs Browser development coordination

docs.title: Tauri Mode (Production)
docs.text:
• Database: SQLite via Rust backend (fast, reliable)
  • Features: AI (Claude/Gemini CLI), Obsidian sync, Pandoc export, Zotero
  • Distribution: macOS .dmg, Windows .exe, Linux AppImage
  • Use case: Daily writing, full functionality

docs.title: Browser Mode (Development)
docs.text:
• Database: IndexedDB via Dexie.js (persists in browser)
  • Features: Core CRUD, search, tags, backlinks, UI testing
  • Distribution: None needed - runs at localhost:5173
  • Use cases:
  • UI development without Rust compilation
  • Testing on different browsers
  • Demos and screenshots
  • CI/CD testing

docs.title: When to Use Tauri Mode
docs.text:
npm run dev
- Testing Rust backend changes - Testing native features (AI, export, sync) - Final integration testing - Building release binaries

docs.title: When to Use Browser Mode
docs.text:
npm run dev:vite
- UI/UX development (faster HMR) - Component styling and layout - Testing search, tags, backlinks - Creating demos or screenshots - Browser compatibility testing

docs.title: Key Files
docs.text: File Purpose lib/platform.ts isTauri(), isBrowser() detection lib/api.ts Factory that exports correct API lib/browser-api.ts IndexedDB implementation (46 operations) lib/browser-db.ts Dexie.js schema + seed data lib/browser-dialogs.ts Browser confirm()/alert() fallbacks

docs.title: 1. Single Source of Truth
docs.text:
• UI components: One set of React components, works in both modes
  • Types: Shared TypeScript types in types/
  • State: Zustand store works identically in both

docs.title: 2. API Parity
docs.text:
• browserApi implements all 46 operations from tauriApi
  • Stubbed methods return sensible defaults or messages
  • Example: runClaude() returns "AI requires desktop app"

docs.title: 3. Test in Browser First
docs.text: For UI changes: 1. Start with npm run dev:vite (fast, no Rust) 2. Iterate on UI/UX quickly 3. Test in Tauri when stable

docs.title: 4. Feature Flags by Platform
docs.text:
// In components
if (isBrowser()) {
  // Show "Browser Mode" badge
  // Hide AI buttons or show "desktop only" tooltip
}

docs.title: Feature Availability Matrix
docs.text: Feature Tauri Browser Notes Create/Edit Notes ✅ ✅ Full parity Projects ✅ ✅ Full parity Tags ✅ ✅ Full parity Backlinks ✅ ✅ Full parity Full-text Search ✅ ✅ Browser uses simple search Command Palette ✅ ✅ Full parity Daily Notes ✅ ✅ Full parity Claude AI ✅ ❌ Requires CLI Gemini AI ✅ ❌ Requires CLI Obsidian Sync ✅ ❌ Requires filesystem PDF/Word Export ✅ ❌ Requires Pandoc Zotero Citations ✅ ❌ Requires Zotero Window Dragging ✅ ❌ Native window API

docs.title: If the feature is UI-only:
docs.text:
1. Develop in browser mode (fast iteration)
  2. No changes to api.ts needed
  3. Test in Tauri before merge

docs.title: If the feature needs backend:
docs.text:
1. Add to Tauri backend first (src-tauri/)
  2. Add to tauriApi in api.ts
  3. Add stub to browserApi (return default or message)
  4. Test in both modes

docs.text:
// api.ts - tauriApi
exportToPdf: (noteId: string): Promise<string> =>
  invoke('export_to_pdf', { noteId }),

// browser-api.ts - browserApi
exportToPdf: async (_noteId: string): Promise<string> => {
  return 'PDF export requires the desktop app'
}

The scribe browser command launches browser mode: 

scribe browser              # Opens Chrome at localhost:5173

This is useful for: - Quick demos without launching full Tauri app - Testing on machines without Rust toolchain - CI/CD environments

docs.title: Window Title (Phase 1)
docs.text:
File: src-tauri/tauri.conf.json

The title is static in config. Options: 1. Build-time injection: Use Tauri's beforeBuildCommand to modify config 2. Runtime update: Use Tauri's window API to set title on app start

Recommended: Runtime update

// src-tauri/src/main.rs or lib.rs
fn setup_window_title(app: &tauri::App) {
    if cfg!(debug_assertions) {
        let branch = std::process::Command::new("git")
            .args(["rev-parse", "--abbrev-ref", "HEAD"])
            .output()
            .map(|o| String::from_utf8_lossy(&o.stdout).trim().to_string())
            .unwrap_or_default();

        if let Some(window) = app.get_window("main") {
            let title = format!("Scribe [{}]", branch);
            window.set_title(&title).ok();
        }
    }
}

docs.title: Tauri Enhancement Proposals
docs.text: Generated: 2025-12-30 Context: Post-integration improvements for Tauri backend

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: With Tauri SQLite now at parity with browser IndexedDB, these enhancements would add validation, search capabilities, and cross-platform sync.

docs.title: 1. Property Type Validation in Rust
docs.text:
Effort: ⚡ Quick Files: src-tauri/src/database.rs

Currently properties are stored as raw JSON strings. Add validation before insert/update.

#[derive(Debug, Serialize, Deserialize)]
pub struct Property {
    pub key: String,
    pub value: serde_json::Value,
    #[serde(rename = "type")]
    pub prop_type: PropertyType,
    #[serde(default)]
    pub readonly: bool,
}

#[derive(Debug, Serialize, Deserialize)]
#[serde(rename_all = "lowercase")]
pub enum PropertyType {
    Text,
    Date,
    Number,
    Checkbox,
    List,
    Link,
    Tags,
}

fn validate_properties(json: &str) -> Result<(), String> {
    let props: HashMap<String, Property> = serde_json::from_str(json)
        .map_err(|e| format!("Invalid properties JSON: {}", e))?;

    for (key, prop) in props {
        match (&prop.prop_type, &prop.value) {
            (PropertyType::Number, v) if !v.is_number() => {
                return Err(format!("Property '{}' should be a number", key));
            }
            (PropertyType::Checkbox, v) if !v.is_boolean() => {
                return Err(format!("Property '{}' should be a boolean", key));
            }
            (PropertyType::List | PropertyType::Tags, v) if !v.is_array() => {
                return Err(format!("Property '{}' should be an array", key));
            }
            _ => {}
        }
    }
    Ok(())
}

Benefit: Catch malformed data early, better error messages

docs.title: 2. Add Property to Search Index
docs.text:
Effort: ⚡ Quick Files: src-tauri/src/database.rs

Include property values in search_text column for full-text search.

fn build_search_text(title: &str, content: &str, properties: Option<&str>) -> String {
    let mut text = format!("{} {}", title, content);

    if let Some(props_json) = properties {
        if let Ok(props) = serde_json::from_str::<HashMap<String, Property>>(props_json) {
            for (key, prop) in props {
                text.push(' ');
                text.push_str(&key);
                text.push(' ');
                match &prop.value {
                    serde_json::Value::String(s) => text.push_str(s),
                    serde_json::Value::Array(arr) => {
                        for v in arr {
                            if let Some(s) = v.as_str() {
                                text.push(' ');
                                text.push_str(s);
                            }
                        }
                    }
                    v => text.push_str(&v.to_string()),
                }
            }
        }
    }
    text
}

Benefit: Search finds notes by property values (e.g., search "due:2025-01-15")

docs.title: 3. Property-Specific Search/Filter API
docs.text:
Effort: 🔧 Medium Files: src-tauri/src/database.rs, src-tauri/src/commands.rs

Add commands to filter notes by property values.

#[tauri::command]
pub fn filter_notes_by_property(
    state: State<AppState>,
    property_key: String,
    property_value: Option<String>,
    operator: Option<String>, // "eq", "contains", "gt", "lt", "exists"
) -> Result<Vec<Note>, String> {
    let db = state.db.lock().unwrap();
    db.filter_by_property(&property_key, property_value.as_deref(), operator.as_deref())
        .map_err(|e| e.to_string())
}

Use cases: - Find all notes with status: draft - Find notes where due date is before today - Find notes that have a project property (exists check)

docs.title: 4. Export/Import for Browser ↔ Tauri Sync
docs.text:
Effort: 🔧 Medium Files: New src-tauri/src/sync.rs, commands

Create JSON export/import for moving data between browser and Tauri.

#[derive(Serialize, Deserialize)]
pub struct ExportData {
    pub version: u32,
    pub exported_at: i64,
    pub notes: Vec<Note>,
    pub tags: Vec<Tag>,
    pub note_tags: Vec<NoteTag>,
    pub links: Vec<Link>,
    pub projects: Vec<Project>,
    pub project_settings: Vec<ProjectSettings>,
}

#[tauri::command]
pub fn export_database(state: State<AppState>) -> Result<ExportData, String>

#[tauri::command]
pub fn import_database(state: State<AppState>, data: ExportData, merge: bool) -> Result<ImportResult, String>

Options: - merge: true — Merge with existing data (update if newer) - merge: false — Replace all data

Benefit: Users can switch between browser demo and Tauri app seamlessly

docs.title: 5. Real-time Sync via File Watcher
docs.text:
Effort: 🏗️ Large

Watch a shared JSON file for changes, enabling: - Multiple Scribe instances syncing - External tools modifying notes - Obsidian-style vault sync

docs.title: Recommended Path
docs.text:
→ Start with #1 (Property Type Validation) — Prevents data corruption, < 30 min

Then: 1. #2 (Search index) — Immediate UX improvement 2. #3 (Filter API) — Enables advanced queries 3. #4 (Export/Import) — Nice-to-have for power users

docs.text: Enhancement Adds Complexity? User-Facing? Priority Type validation Low Indirect (errors) High Search indexing Low Yes High Property filter API Medium Yes Medium Export/Import Medium Yes Low Real-time sync High Yes Defer

Critical Issues: - Sprint 8 marked complete but BlockNote migration never happened - BlockNote packages not installed in package.json - App using HybridEditor (markdown textarea + preview mode) instead of BlockNote - Dead code exists: BlockNoteEditor.tsx, Editor.tsx, extensions/ - Wiki-link "[[" only works in preview mode, not write mode - No inline autocomplete for wiki-links or tags

What Actually Works: - HybridEditor with write/preview mode toggle (⌘E) - Focus mode (⌘⇧F / Escape) - Word count footer - Dark theme default - PARA folder structure (Inbox, Projects, Areas, Resources, Archive) - SQLite database with notes, folders, links, tags - Full-text search (SQLite FTS5) - ReactMarkdown preview with basic wiki-link and tag rendering

What Needs Decision (Sprint 9): Option A: Fix HybridEditor bugs (2-3h) - quick, stable Option B: Complete BlockNote migration (6-8h) - as planned, complex Option C: Switch to TipTap (4-6h) - alternative rich editor Option D: HybridEditor++ (3-4h) - enhance markdown with autocomplete

Decision: Option D (HybridEditor++) implemented ✅

docs.title: 🎯 One Sentence
docs.text: Scribe = ADHD-friendly distraction-free writer + projects + academic features + CLI-based AI.

docs.title: ⚡ TL;DR (30 seconds)
docs.text: What How Editor HybridEditor (markdown + preview) Focus Distraction-free mode, global hotkey Projects Research, Teaching, R-Package, R-Dev, Generic Citations Zotero via Better BibTeX Export Markdown, LaTeX, PDF, Word, Quarto AI Claude + Gemini CLI (no API keys) Notes Wiki links, tags, daily notes Storage Local project folders + Obsidian sync Design ADHD-first, minimal friction

docs.title: 🧠 ADHD Design Principles
docs.text: These override ALL feature decisions.

docs.title: 1. Zero Friction (< 3 seconds)
docs.text:
⌘⇧N → Window appears → Start typing
No dialogs. No choices. Just write.

docs.title: 2. One Thing at a Time
docs.text:
• Single note visible
  • Sidebar collapses in focus mode
  • No tabs, no split views

docs.title: 3. Escape Hatches
docs.text:
• ⌘W = Close (auto-saves)
  • ⌘Z = Undo (always works)
  • No "Are you sure?" dialogs

docs.title: 4. Visible Progress
docs.text:
• Word count (always visible)
  • Session timer
  • Streak indicator (optional)

docs.title: 5. Sensory-Friendly
docs.text:
• Dark mode default
  • No distracting animations
  • Muted colors, high contrast text

docs.title: 6. Quick Wins
docs.text:
• Milestone celebrations (100, 500, 1000 words)
  • "Win" logging
  • Daily goal progress bar

docs.title: ✅ What Scribe IS
docs.text: Principle Implementation Distraction-Free Writer Focus mode, minimal UI Markdown Editor Write/Preview mode with live markdown rendering Project Manager Local folders, project settings Academic Writing Tool Zotero + LaTeX + Quarto Knowledge Notes Wiki links, tags, daily notes ADHD-Friendly Quick capture, low friction CLI-Based AI claude and gemini CLI Obsidian Companion Sync notes to vault

docs.title: ❌ What Scribe IS NOT
docs.text: Avoid Why Full IDE Use VS Code / Positron Terminal emulator Defer to v2 (use iTerm/Wezterm) Code editor Use VS Code / RStudio Full PKM system Obsidian does this Graph view Too complex, use Obsidian API-based AI Requires keys, costs money Plugin system Scope creep Multi-tab editor Breaks "one thing at a time"

docs.text:
Scribe uses a Notion-style block editor:

Type / to see block options:
/heading    → Create heading
/list       → Bullet list
/todo       → Checklist
/code       → Code block
/quote      → Blockquote

docs.title: Focus Mode
docs.text:
Press ⌘. to enter distraction-free mode:

  • Sidebar hides
  • Editor centers
  • Background dims

Press ⌘. again to exit.

docs.title: Word Count
docs.text: Always visible in status bar at bottom.

docs.title: Project Types
docs.text: Type Use Case Research Papers, analysis Teaching Courses, lectures R-Package R package docs R-Dev Dev tools Generic Everything else

docs.title: Creating a Project
docs.text:
1. Click ⚙️ New Project in sidebar
  2. Choose project type
  3. Name your project
  4. Select folder location

docs.title: Project Structure
docs.text:
~/Projects/my-research/
├── .scribe/
│   └── project.json    # Settings
├── paper-draft.md
└── daily/
    └── 2024-12-24.md

docs.title: Project Settings
docs.text:
Edit .scribe/project.json:

{
  "name": "My Research",
  "type": "research",
  "bibliography": "~/Zotero/research.bib",
  "obsidianVault": "~/vaults/research",
  "exportDefaults": {
    "format": "pdf",
    "citationStyle": "apa7"
  }
}

docs.title: Creating Daily Notes
docs.text: Press ⌘D to open/create today's note.

docs.title: Daily Note Template
docs.text:
## 2024-12-24

### Progress
- [ ] Task 1
- [ ] Task 2

### Notes

### Tags
#daily

docs.title: Customizing Template
docs.text:
Edit project settings:

{
  "dailyNotes": {
    "enabled": true,
    "folder": "daily",
    "template": "## {{date}}\n\n### Progress\n\n### Notes\n"
  }
}

docs.text:

docs.title: Navigation
docs.text: Click a wiki link to jump to that note.

docs.title: Backlinks
docs.text: The sidebar shows notes that link to the current note.

docs.title: Adding Tags
docs.text:
Type # to trigger autocomplete:

This is about #research and #causal-inference.

docs.title: Tag Colors
docs.text: Tags automatically get consistent colors based on their name.

docs.title: Filtering by Tag
docs.text: Click a tag in the Tags panel to filter notes.

docs.title: Available Actions
docs.text: Action What it does Improve Enhance clarity and flow Expand Develop the idea further Summarize Condense to key points Explain Simplify complex text Research Find related information

docs.title: Using AI
docs.text:
1. Select text
  2. Press ⌘⇧A (or right-click → AI)
  3. Choose action
  4. Select provider (Claude or Gemini)

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
# Claude CLI
claude --version

# Gemini CLI
gemini --version

No API keys needed — uses your CLI subscriptions.

docs.title: Supported Formats
docs.text: Format Extension Requirements Markdown .md None LaTeX .tex Pandoc PDF .pdf Pandoc + LaTeX Word .docx Pandoc Quarto .qmd Quarto

docs.title: Exporting
docs.text:
1. Open note
  2. Press ⌘E or File → Export
  3. Choose format
  4. Select location

docs.title: Citations
docs.text:
If you have Zotero configured:

  1. Citations auto-link from @citekey
  2. Bibliography appended to export
  3. Citation style based on project settings

docs.title: App Won't Start
docs.text:
# Clear cache and reinstall
rm -rf node_modules
npm install
npm run dev

docs.title: Database Issues
docs.text:
# Database location
~/.config/scribe/scribe.db

# Reset (caution: deletes notes)
rm ~/.config/scribe/scribe.db

docs.title: Export Fails
docs.text:
# Check Pandoc
pandoc --version

# Check LaTeX (for PDF)
pdflatex --version

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: Get Scribe running in under 2 minutes.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Node.js 18+
  • npm 9+

docs.title: Install & Run
docs.text:
# Clone (if not already)
cd ~/projects/dev-tools/scribe

# Install dependencies
npm install

# Start development
npm run dev

docs.title: First Note
docs.text:
1. App opens with sidebar
  2. Click + New Note or press ⌘N
  3. Start typing
